Title.evidence: A multicentre, non-inferiority RCT was conducted

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomized to receive SAP or TAP.

Participants.evidence: patients with an incompetent great saphenous vein or anterior accessory saphenous vein with one or more incompetent tributaries.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomized to receive SAP or TAP.

Objective.evidence: The aim of this study was to determine whether single ambulatory phlebectomy with or without delayed endovenous truncal ablation (SAP) is non-inferior to thermal endovenous ablation with concomitant phlebectomy (TAP), and whether SAP is a cost-effective alternative to TAP.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was VEnous INsufficiency Epidemiological and Economic Study Quality of Life/Symptoms (VEINES-QOL/Sym score) after 12 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Participants were randomized to receive SAP or TAP.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Some 464 patients received the allocated treatment (SAP 227, TAP 237).

Result_Outcome.evidence: VEINES-QOL scores were 52.7 (95 per cent c.i. 51.9 to 53.9) for SAP and 53.8 (53.3 to 55.1) for TAP; VEINES-Sym scores were 53.5 (52.6 to 54.4) and 54.2 (54.0 to 55.6) respectively.
